content.description:
Wide cracks in a right-facing corner lead up to a tight squeeze and a leftward traverse to a big wide ledge. Traverse this further left to a brief boulder problem and a broken corner that ends at a bolted anchor and a vegetated ledge which provides access to the upper tier.

 There is currently a red rope hanging down the length of this "route".
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, series of cracks and ledges following a weakness to the upper ledge

content.description: Starts wide and stays that way most of the way. Slither up into it, finding hands and fists where you can, along with face holds that present themselves. Stemming and foot jamming will help you along. Arrive at a pedestal about 30' up and continue your upward journey at the back of it. Still wide now, but more chimney technique and stemming. Several cracks intersect higher up, allowing for more grabby holds, and then pull a bulgy hand crack section to a stance at a bolt. Finish up a loose, dirty slot to a solid chain-and-rings anchor at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Lots of wide, probably a couple 5" and a 6", with some smaller stuff down to 2"
content.location: From the top of the main trail, identify a tall block below a hand crack (this is Murky Waters), follow two bolt lines over (these are Zeno's Paradox and Persistence is Futile), and you will see a wide crack going up to a ledge and then continuing up the back of it to the top of the cliff... this is the one!

content.description: Start up the wide crack on the left or, better, the hand crack to left-arching finger crack on the right. If you climb up the right crack, step left onto the pedestal before starting up onto the face. Crimps and baby-bottom slopers present a sequence of challenging moves through this section, before the angle eases. Climb a radical left-arching hand crack to an odd mantel and a bolt. Step back right and climb this seam that becomes a crack, using face holds on the left. Continue up the crack to the anchors. Beware of loose stuff near the top.
content.protection: Gear to 3", 6 bolts, anchors with chains
content.location: From where the trail meets the wall at Murky Waters, it's the third bolt line to the right. The first bolt is at ~35' moving up and right from a large ledge towards a vine maple.

content.description: Wide placements in the middle of the route are obvious, then the best climbing is above: sustained 1-2 inch jamming and stemming leads to a few exciting but well protected face moves to reach the anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 5 inch, though if you're creative and 10b is nowhere near your limit you could do without the #5 (but I wouldn't).

content.description:
Maybe this isn't a route yet? Looks like someone has been doing a bunch of moss-removal over here. This one may not be worth the effort though.

 Step left under and around the bulge overhang to a stance below the minor roof. Surmount this with good holds that may be covered in moss and dirt. Once on the slab, continue upward into a crack and a ever-tightening slot. Shimmy past this to a ledge which, as of now, only has two widely-spaced bolts with rope and quick-link for an anchor.

 You could also continue another 25' higher (following the red rope) up the broken corner to a higher anchor. This provides access to the upper tier.
content.protection: Gear to 3"? Probably needs bolts down low
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, rightward-trending weakness on the left side of a short bulgy wall

content.description: Impossible from directly below the first bolt. Start up near the wide crack, almost level with the first bolt. Pull chunky, not-very-inspiring holds up and around this overhang, to slightly better holds above. Trend right a little bit, away from the better holds out left. Attempt to layback at a sloping rail? Or maybe step out left away from the last bolt? Weird sequence here, but eventually find yourself at a slab that takes you up to the big wide ledge. Use the rope and quick-link anchor for rappel until a better one gets installed.
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, 3-bolt problem up the bulgy clean wall

content.description: Climb up a thin seam to the first bolt, then move left where it widens then disappears. Really cool face features appear in its place. Utilize right hand side-pulls and the left hand arete to pull the crux, then step right. Get into the crack and finish up into the alcove above and to the right.
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, the obvious slice of vertical face between the wide cracks on the left and a narrow bolted arete on the right

content.description: Tenuous start on small holds with lots of moss and fir needles. Balance up to a slight bulge and navigating this on positive crimps. Step up to a sloping stance and grapple with the blank bulge. Sort out a cryptic sequence then follow the rounded arete upwards to another stance below a crack at your left hand and a contrived overhang. Beware of loose rock here. Pull a surprisingly fun and juggy sequence and step back left to the crack. At a horizonal break, do some funky stemming and crimping to a slopey leftward traverse to the anchor.
content.location: Far left side of the established (clean) section of wall. Right-hand route at this undulating strip of relatively tall rock.

content.description: Make funky stemming moves below a low bulge to work your way out onto the left face and around this. Cruise up the now slabby but dirty face to another bulge, this one taller and more crumbly. Crucial holds are likely to come off of this route over time, so pull carefully. The gully to the right looks inviting but doesn't yield any better climbing. Another slab, then another overhang with loose rock. Pull big holds to a strenuous layback crack. Continue up and left to a brief arete and anchors.
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, left of a pair of bolted lines up this undulating strip of relatively tall rock

content.description: Mantle onto the obvious 10 foot block leaning against the cliff right where the trail hits the cliff. In 2010 this was the only route with an apparent anchor, and you can see why is was perhaps the first route done here. Standard and stout hand crack, go get some.
content.location: Where the trail hits the wall, this hand crack starts above the obvious 10 foot block leaning against the cliff

content.description: Start up the right side of the wide crack system. At a right-arching flake system step right and climb this, clipping bolts to your left. Finger jams and face holds give way to a dirty finish.
content.protection: Gear to 3", 3 bolts, anchor with bailer 'biners
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, climb the bolted flake between the wide crack system and the bolted face of Oasis

content.description: Start up an easy wide Â crack ramp to where the headwall steepens following discontinuous cracks and ledges. Follow the thin steep crack to the top, avoid the overhang on the top by going to the right through the narrow chimney to the rap anchors. A 60m rope will just barely get you back to the ground.
content.location: Right side wall, amphitheater area, right side of the scoop

content.description: Follow the line of corroding bolts placed every 2-3' next to an easily protectable crack (ugh). A tight squeeze down low leads into low-angle wide crack swimming. Work your way up and then eventually out right to a ledge and bolted anchor. You could go higher, where there is a high-quality stainless lower-off, but you might as well just end at the obvious ledge and avoid the extra easy mossy off-width. This anchor serves two other routes - the right side of the crack system and a 3-bolt variation.
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, obvious wide crack system leading up into the dark mossy beyond

content.description:
Still dirty, could use some brushing through the middle, but an otherwise stellar line up a wild feature.

 Start in an alcove to the left of the amphitheater. You can place gear here and as you traverse under the low roof. The reach out to the first bolt and the pull past it is a bit nerve-wracking. From here climb fairly straightforward but thought-provoking rock to a stance below a slightly right-leaning rail. A very distinct crux forces you to smear rightward on slopey and/or crimpy holds with no feet to a jug on the arete. From here it's a cruise up a crack to the top.

 Apparently there are more possibilities above, but we didn't check them out.
content.protection: 9 bolts? minor gear recommended at the start, anchors with lower-off hardware
content.location: Far right side of the area, just left of the obvious amphitheater, climbs the left/backside of the overhanging arete.

content.description: Not a great beginner's lead, despite the grade. Tricky protection and unintuitive movement define this short, decent, heady route. Start up as for Slanted then step right before getting into the off-width. Protect where/how you can and make surprisingly moderate moves up steep-ish rock with good stances. No stance for the anchor though so feel free to grab the chains!
content.protection: Gear to 2", mostly smaller stuff. Offset nuts recommended. Anchor with chains.
content.location: Middle/left of the main wall, on a slight mound above where the main trail meets the wall

content.description: Right side of the crack system that goes up into the dark moss beyond. This side has much better climbing though, as it includes a fun section of hand crack. Stay left of the bolt line and flakes, stemming back when you can. End in a channel of dirt that's easy to avoid and scramble up to the ledge.
content.location: Far left side of the established (ie: clean) section of wall, right side of the obvious wide crack system

content.description: An awkward and grovelly route that may be more worthwhile if climbing the variations to left or right. As is, it's not a lot of fun unless you really enjoy shimmying dirty chimneys. Start up multiple stances to a right-trending crack and a vertical left-hand rail. Get creative with your pro and pull a low crux. Once in the chimney, clip widely-spaced bolts up to an arbitrary ending point with no feet and a set of long chains.
content.protection: Gear to 3", 2 bolts. Anchor with chains.
content.location: Left side of the main area, just right of a big wide chasm formed by the short arete of Pygmy and the wall behind. Right-trending crack that widens to a chimney at the top.

content.description: What is it that has kept this beautiful crag off the map for so long? Maybe it's the arduous approach hike. Maybe it's the lack of concentrated development. Maybe it's the absence from popular local guidebooks. Whatever the reasons may be, disregard them, as the Hunch is definitely worthy of exploration and could definitely use some traffic to keep clean / re-clean / continue cleaning routes.This is a crag of approachable extremes. The hike is what it is: ~25 minutes of steep uphill schlepping on a very obvious, well-maintained trail (once you find it). The cracks go at generally moderate grades, though some bow out into uncomfortably-wide territory, while the face climbs start at the high end of "moderate" and progress immediately to the "extreme" end (think Broughton's Bat Wall at elevation with different features). A plethora of development opportunities remain which will involve a lot of moss scrubbing and/or hard-ass face climbing. What's already established presents at least a few days worth of fun to justify the hike. Supposing some intrepid developers were to fill in the obvious lines that remain, including the upper tier, and we'd have ourselves a veritable destination crag without the obnoxious crowds.As it stands, it's a wonderful destination for 11-13 sport climbers and 9-10 trad climbers willing to lug extras in the 2-4" range. So like, umm, maybe the best Feb-July trad climbing within an hour of Portland?The area has a relatively long season, being that it sits at 2,100 feet in elevation and is oriented in a somewhat southwesterly direction. The tall fir trees make that a bit complicated in the best way - they add shade in the summer, even if they hold a little moisture in the early spring and late fall. When compared to French's Dome, it is actually lower in elevation and has a more southerly aspect.It is within the Mt. Hood National Forest so no access concerns currently exist. Conveniently, a NW Forest Pass is not necessary. Parking on the narrow shoulder allows for only 3-4 cars.Tim Olson's website with beta
